Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Stable sheaves, stable quotients, stable pairs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will work on a wide range of research projects related to the geometry and intersection theory of moduli spaces in algebraic geometry.Three main directions are proposed. First, the PI will study Le Potier's strange duality conjecture for spaces of generalized theta functions. Along the way, the author will investigate questions related to the tautological rings of the moduli space of K3 surfaces, abelian surfaces, and Calabi-Yau manifolds, the positivity of the theta linear series, and the Brill-Noether theory of sheaves over higher dimensional bases. A second direction concerns intersection theoretic calculations on the moduli space of stable quotients for local toric and hypersurface geometries, and their comparison with Gromov-Witten theory. Thirdly, the author plans to compute stable pair invariants of local curve and surface geometries by comparison with intersection theory of Quot scheme, a topic which has been at the center of the PI's research in recent years.

The PI works in algebraic geometry, which is the study of solutions of polynomial equations. More specifically, the PI's research focuses on moduli theory and enumerative geometry. Moduli spaces put together objects with similar structure, with the goal of obtaining a global unified view of the structure under study, both qualitatively and quantitatively. This will be beneficial for algebraic geometry, but also for a number of related fields. In recent years, the PI mentored undergraduate and graduate students in areas close to his research, and will continue to do so. He plans to develop new algebraic geometry courses, and to write an undergraduate algebraic geometry text. He will co-organize a seminar at his institution, as well as the Southern California Algebraic Geometry Seminar. Furthermore, the PI will organize workshops focusing on topics related to moduli spaces of sheaves. Finally, the PI will be involved in high school and college competitions, and in the preparation of gifted high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's research is in algebraic geometry, in particular in moduli  theory. Moduli spaces are parameter spaces of objects with similar structure. The PI studied several types of moduli spaces from different perspectives. Six research directions were pursued during the award period. The first direction concerned the moduli space of stable sheaves and the strange duality conjecture, a difficult open problem in the field. Here, the PI and his collaborators investigated the strange duality conjecture for K3 surfaces, elliptic surfaces and abelian surfaces. In a second direction, the PI and his collaborators studied a very interesting class of bundles over the moduli space of curves, termed Verlinde bundles, and determined several invariants of these objects. In a third direction, the PI and his collaborators studied the moduli space of K3 surfaces and its tautological ring, proposing a method to obtain relations between tautological classes. A fourth direction concerned the intersection theory of the Hilbert scheme of points on surfaces -- here the PI and his collaborators studied a conjecture of M. Lehn from 1999. A fifth direction concerned a class of semihomogeneous vector bundles over abelian varieties. A sixth direction deals with moduli spaces of framed sheaves.

In addition to the research papers above, the PI also wrote a set of expository lecture notes on the moduli space of stable quotients. These notes were used for an advanced graduate summer school. 

For the duration of the award, the PI organized 4 workshops/conferences on topics related to his research (2014, 2016, 2017, 2019). These workshops attracted each time at least 50 participants. The PI also organized the  Western Algebraic Geometry Symposium (2013), one of the largest regular meetings in his field, where the participant count was close to 100. In addition, the PI co-organized 9 editions of the Southern California Algebraic Geometry Seminar, a meeting intended to foster connections between the researchers in the southern california. Finally, the PI co-organized the algebraic geometry seminar at his institution.  

The PI mentored students at various stages of their mathematical education: undergraduate students, master students, PhD students and postdocs. In order to contribute to the graduate program, the PI taught a number of topics courses in his area of research, some of them for the first time at his institution. The PI has made an effort to involve undergraduate students (in addition to graduate students and postdocs) into his research. At the high school level, the PI co-organized 6 editions of the San Diego Honors Math competition. The PI was also a lecturer for the San Diego Math Circle.

The PI gave more than 35 lectures at international conferences, seminars, colloquia, summer schools. The PI also lectured in graduate and undergraduate colloquia in order to popularize the results of his research.

The PI was several times member of the Diversity Committee in his department, whose are to promote diversity in mathematics and beyond.
